child.geography: Cachuy, Tupe district, Yauyos province, Peru

child.pub-comments: Although Kawki and Aymara are more closely related genetically, Kawki and Jaqaru are now in closer contact and share some features to the exclusion of Aymara. "...la relación de las tres lenguas entre sí, con el Jaqaru y el Aymara en los dos extremos de diferenciación y el Kawki en posición intermedia, no obstante la posición geográfica actual, con el Jaqaru y el Kawki en contacto y el Aymara a tres cordilleras de distancia. De especial interés es la evidencia en favor de la temprana separación del Jaqaru del proto-Jaqi, con separación ya tardía entre el Kawki y el Aymara." (Proto-Jaqi: reconstrucción del sistema de personas gramaticales, 1975:452)

root.pub-comments: "The choice of this name should be explained, because other names (Aymara, Aru, Jaqimara) have been used. Because today the Aymara group is by far the largest, it is common practice to refer to the other languages as "dialects" of Aymara. However, the word Aymara in Jaqaru and Kawki is a term used for insult or criticism, lazy, no-good person. The term itself means nothing in Aymara. Apart from other obvious considerations, the term was rejected because it would be insulting to the speakers of the other languages. More seriously, the term Aru has been proposed (see A. Torero, "Lingüistica e Historia de la Socieded Andina," Anales Cientificos de la Universidad Nacional Agraria 3-4 [1970]: 237-44). This term, meaning language, to speak in Jaqaru and Kawki, would be satisfactory for that branch of the family. However, in Aymara, the Spanish borrowing parlaña has replaced the older term in the meaning to speak, leaving aruña for animals and poor or fighting speech, although the noun root aru is used in compounds meaning language. Nevertheless, the implication of aru for the Aymara today is that of something less than human, and for that reason it is rejected. The term Jaqi in all of the languages of the family is people; its impact is invariably positive throughout the family; speakers of all of the languages have agreed to the term. The root occurs in the language name Jaqaru, but, from a synchronic point of view, this is coincidental. Jaqaru is literally people speech, but is not so interpreted today; it is rather simply the name of the language, which, curiously, the people of Tupe translate into Spanish as Cauqui. I once proposed the term Jaqimara-an invention in view of the large number of Aymara speakers; I now consider it a poor choice. The name Jaqi thus is established, with insult to no one and dignity to all." (Jaqi: The Linguistic Family 1978:146-47)
